title: College Preparatory Communication Skills

vocab.definition: Formal style of communication used in scholarly settings
Clear, specific claim that guides entire academic essay
Facts, examples, or expert opinions supporting arguments
Level of language appropriate for academic and professional contexts
Process of having others evaluate and improve your work

teachingNotes: Focus on transition from high school to college-level expectations. Practice academic writing conventions.

shortanswer.question: Explain what academic discourse means and why it matters.
expectedAny: academic discourse is formal scholarly communication essential for college success
the formal language style used in academic settings to convey ideas clearly
professional communication expected in college and career contexts

shortanswer.question: What makes a thesis statement effective?
expectedAny: a clear specific claim that guides the entire essay and is arguable
an effective thesis presents a focused argument the paper will support
specificity and clarity that establishes the essay's purpose

shortanswer.question: Why is evidence important in academic writing?
expectedAny: evidence supports claims with facts and makes arguments credible
facts and examples strengthen arguments and convince readers
credible support demonstrates research and validates claims

shortanswer.question: Describe what formal register means in writing.
expectedAny: formal register is professional language avoiding contractions and slang
the appropriate academic tone for scholarly and professional contexts
elevated language level suitable for formal communication

shortanswer.question: How does peer review improve writing?
expectedAny: peer review provides feedback that helps identify weaknesses and strengthen arguments
others offer perspectives that improve clarity and organization
collaborative evaluation catches errors and enhances quality

shortanswer.question: What is the difference between academic and casual discourse?
expectedAny: academic discourse is formal and structured while casual is informal and conversational
academic requires evidence and precision while casual allows opinions and slang
scholarly communication follows conventions that casual speech does not

shortanswer.question: Give an example of strong evidence in an essay.
expectedAny: statistics from credible research studies supporting the claim
expert opinions from published scholars in the field
documented facts and data from reliable sources

shortanswer.question: Why should writers avoid contractions in formal writing?
expectedAny: contractions are too casual for academic and professional contexts
formal register maintains professional tone without informal shortcuts
academic writing requires complete words for clarity and professionalism

shortanswer.question: How can peer review help with thesis development?
expectedAny: peers can identify when a thesis lacks clarity or specificity
feedback helps refine arguments and make claims more focused
collaborative review ensures the thesis effectively guides the essay

shortanswer.question: Why is learning academic discourse important for college?
expectedAny: college requires formal communication for essays and discussions
academic discourse is essential for success in scholarly environments
professional communication skills are necessary for college and careers
